A very well-made horror game with an interesting concept, where you can create your own strategy to survive through 5 nights (actually there is 7 nights) as a security guard at Freddy Fazbear's pizza. Basically you're in a room with cameras and doors with lights to press if your enemies are outside the door beacuse you won't be able to see them very well in the darkness which will be a problem then... Your enemies by the way are 4 animatronic characters that will get more active the more progress you make on your nights... the first one is a bunny called: Bonnie. The second one is a chicken called: Chica... and the third one is a bear named Freddy (which is the main antagonist in the game) and the fourth one is a fox called: Foxy. they are going to try to kill you when they get a great chance and you have to stop these chances and survive through the nights... but be aware of the power you have to left side in the bottom corner... if it runs out you will die... possibly... or maybe if you're lucky you can actually make it to the next night... oh i forgot to mention: you have to work your shifts from 12 am to 6 am in the game... and the only help you get is from a guy on the phone, cameras and the doors that can be closed to stop them from coming in... sometimes you can't close the doors that means that you're doomed... because one of them is in your room and will kill you if you put up and then down the camera... You have to watch every one of them on the camera to make sure they don't move so often... but more necessary... only check on Freddy and Foxy... beacause those two are the actual problems in this game... because they can kill you very easily if you don't check on them too often... but you need to be aware of the other two too: Bonnie and Chica... but Bonnie is more active than Chica is... so you don't need to check on Chica too much... but then there are the other two... or actually THE THREE problems: Bonnie, Freddy and Foxy that you need to guard (you can hear Bonnie and Chica step on the floor outside the room sometimes that means that they might or might not be very close to you) ... I highly recommend this game for those who wants to get their socks scared off >:) If you don't find animals scary... Five Nights at Freddy's will prove what kind of hell animals can be...   PS: there is a fifth animal called: Golden Freddy... and he can be found in your office if you look on the cameras on a poster in one room too much... and if you stare on him too much he will crash your game and end the attempt you're doing in this game... so get rid of him by going back to the cameras, because then he'll disappear...

Despite the franchise's fandom being considered to be one of the worst fandoms out there, I overall enjoyed this game along with it's latter three sequels and two spinoffs. I also enjoyed the franchise's lore and the fact that the games arenow iconic nowdays ever since the first game's release back in 2014 back when it was new. Let's not forget that I have respect for Scott Cawthon on making his fans happy (sames goes to the YouTubers and others who either played FNAF or do anything else FNAF related like Markiplier, Jacksepticeye, Rebornica, Smike, MatPat, etc.), even if FNAF's fanbase is one of the worst out there (despite there are some fans that don't act like your average FNAF fan). Also, when I first watched Markiplier's videos related to the FNAF quadrology, the jumpscares made jump back when expecting jumpscares per new game, but nowadays, I just got used to them. Should I recommend readers like you to buy the game or any of it's sequels or spinoffs? Well, it depends on your opinion due to how much hate FNAF's fanbase has gotten.

How hard could a security guard job be? Even at night?  This game begs to answer the previous question. This little indie game from small beginnings skyrocketed to fame within only a few weeks, and you got to wonder why that is?  In Five Nights at Freddy's, you take the night shift from 12 AM to 6 AM at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza and must make it through the night alive. Yes... ALIVE! Despite you being the only living soul in the place, what would really cause trouble, or rather, who?  Look around your surveillance cameras, take a glance out the doors of the office periodically and see for yourself. Take a listen to the guy on the phone's message to see what the whole business is like. He lays it all out on the table for you, nice and gentle, it's just animatronics, right?  But Freddy disagrees with his deep dark and cold stare through that door of your office...    Thanks for reading! Check out these other links!   My Curator Group   Other Game Reviews

I bought this game months ago and played it on a friends steam instead.  FNaF has a wonderfully complicated story and this game introduces fans to this new story. There is a positive.  I have mixed emotions about the gameplay. The first night is really easy (I played the third game first before any of them;Im kinda new to this game franchise, I used to hate it and think it was overrated.) This game was one of the best indie games of the year...it was wonderfully scary at first and introduced unique and cool game mechanics. But after about two to the three nights, the game loses its scare factor. The jumpscares are predictable and the gameplay becomes slow and boring. 4/20 was nearly impossible to complete. It took over 4 hours to complete and I was playing with a friend...but because it was a one-of-a-kind and brought forward a brand new theme in the horror game genre. But this game drags out. Five nights actually feels like five days...the gameplay can be ridiculously hard and the power drains way to quickly. Positive and negative.   The style is amazing. I love the designs of the animatronic characters and I like the names. Foxy I think has the best behavior and mechanic to evade him out of the four of them. Its cool to see him running down the hall. The eleven cameras by pulling up a monitor is a cool game mechanic, like I said it introduced a new theme in the horror genre. For a 2014 game, the graphics were pretty cool...the office makes you feel somewhat claustrophobic. Positive.  Overall, because the game was new and introduced a new concept into the horror genre, I would recommend it. The gameplay is fun for the first two to three nights...but afterwards...I dunno. Scott Cawthon did a good job creating a horror game and I think its a bit of the fandoms fault for creating such a bad image for the game with their sensitive comebacks and insanely messed up rule 34 crap...sound effects were cool, characters were wonderfully sculpted and the 4/20 was a good, rageful challenge.   Would recommend.

First Night strategy:  At 1 A.M, close the left door. I like to flash my monitor on Pirate Cove around 4 A.M, only once though. At 5 A.M with about 3% left, open the left door. This worked for me.  Shock horror is very subjective. However, using a jumpscare to shock someone is a very cheap tactic, and you don't get shocked because it's scary. You get shocked because it's an instinctive reaction. It's really only scary the first couple of times. While I know horror, as well as humor and such, are subjective, I think most can agree that a jumpscare is more of a way to get you screaming rather than a way to get you sleeping with a baseball bat at your side because you are having night terrors. LASTING IMPRESSIONS Five Nights at Freddy's  GENRE Horror/Point-And-Click  STORY Five Nights at Freddy's follows the story of Mike Schmidt, the new night guard for the vintage pizzeria starring the animatronic characters Freddy Fazbear, Chica the Chicken, Bonnie the Bunny, and Foxy the Pirate Fox. Upon starting his first night, Mike is informed by the previous night guard of his duties; check the cameras, make sure everything stays in place, and don't get murdered by the animatronics. You know, the usual. Mike must now survive five(seven) nights in the building making sure to not run out of power, not get murdered by haunted robots, and get his paycheck.  GAMEPLAY The gameplay is fairly basic; easy to learn, hard to master. As your job is to guard the building, you must constantly check the cameras. This will allow you to know where the animatronics are, and keep some of them in place. Along with the camera you have the doors and the lights. The doors are used to keep any and all animatronics at bay should they decide your office would be a nice place to sneak into. The lights will let you know if Bonnie or Chica are outside of their respective doors, so that you may promptly close it right in their faces. Be careful not to forget that this pizzeria has fallen on hard times, and is running on a battery of sorts. All appliances run on this battery, and if you run out of power; it's over.  FINAL THOUGHTS Five Nights at Freddy's is the first horror game I've ever played. In my first couple play sessions I was spooked solid. The game left me on edge, paranoid, and gave me a cold feeling inside. Sadly, the feeling didn't last. After a couple more play sessions it wasn't scary, it was frustrating. It had devolved from a horrific version of Night Trap to Night Guard Simulator 2014. I could only get enjoyment out of it by playing it with friends in a skype call. While I still enjoyed the whole look of the game and got quite engrossed the lore behind it all, I couldn't slog my way through all the nights. Five Nights at Freddy's did not leave a lasting impression, but I'll give it props for trying.  Also, minimum wage for that? Bull. ♥♥♥♥.

I wanted to like this game. Bought it because it was cheap, looked interesting, and everybody all over the internets are crapping themselves playing it, apparently.   I used up all my power quickly on the first night while listening to the jackass on the phone and got killed at like 2 or 3 AM because a big teddy bear appeared and I couldn't close the door. Loaded it up again and pretty much just sat there for 90% staring dead ahead (both in-game and irl) to conserve power, checked the cameras closest to my doors the remaining 10% of the time, and made sure to shut 'em in time if one of the robotic carebear ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s got close. Easy.   Second night was more frustrating. Every time I got to around 3 AM I got jumped by the purple ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ named Bonnie or whatever. I realize the whole game comes down to observing and responding to the patterns of these bigass pooh bear dolls before they jump you and make sweet animatronic love to your corpse, and I realize that if I stuck with it I could figure out these patterns and respond to them appropriately, and I ALSO realize that this is where a lot of the 'fear' that's supposed to drive this game is derived from.   The problem is that I can't find anything compelling enough about its presentation to bother with it.   It's far too formulaic; even if the animatronics have increasingly complex or unpredictable patterns of movement that increase the likelihood of sudden death and generic ho-hum jumpscares (the lamest form of 'horror'), EVERYTHING is rooted in repitition. The interactive element of the game is so sparse it almost feels like you're just clicking on random pictures in a slideshow until 'AHHH uneckspected soscary.gif' inevitably pops up. And they're the same pictures each time. ALL you can do is move the character's perspective left and right while you're in your office or whatever, open up the camera, and check all the security cameras one by one. Oh, and close and open doors and turn lights on and off. That's it.   In theory, the idea of restricting player control in the interest of generating fear is a good one; but it's implemented poorly here due to a lack of variety and a heavy reliance on cheap scares.

I like the ambiance and the setup, but ultimately the game play is too boring.  Partially it might be because the game is mostly just about build up for a jump scare, which I find startling but not scary. But I think the bigger issue is that the game is really just about micro-managing your battery in the most painful way possible.  It also feels like there's an interesting world and story behind everything, but the problem is you don't actually interact with the story. You're just fed (very small) portions of it in the background, but the game play is just hide from the monsters and that's it. The why has no impact on your character, story, or decisions. Among other things, this means I don't get invested in my character at all.  If you're the type of person who likes to get scared, and gets scared by ambiance and jump-scares, than this is probably a good game for you (and yes, I realize that sentence makes me sound condenscending, but I actually mean it legitimately) but otherwise I'd probably avoid the hype.

Five Nights at Freddy's is a frantic horror, small indie game. This game wasn't scary to me but very stressful. You have to beat the clock and not lose your power until 6 A.M. or else you are dead. It took me a while. Unlike other video games I had long periods of time where I avoided playing it because of its stress so it took me a long time to beat it. It is hard to finish what you are not interested in following through on. But eventually I did get to the end beating it at 20/20/20/20. I would give it a 5/10.
